summary: While exploring her new home, a girl named Coraline (Dakota Fanning) discovers a secret door, behind which lies an alternate world that closely mirrors her own but, in many ways, is better. She rejoices in her discovery, until Other Mother (Teri Hatcher) and the rest of her parallel family try to keep her there forever. Coraline must use all her resources and bravery to make it back to her own family and life.

This is my favorite movie by far. It's one of the few movies I can continue to rewatch and rewatch without getting bored. Ever since I first saw it in the movie theaters at 9 years old it captured my heart. I am now 23 and it still captures my heart. It was just wonderfully made and produced. It really touches the heart of your inner child. It deals with the reality of many children in this world, who often have wonderful and awe-inspiring imaginations that don't always get nurtured or heard. I love the idea of the tiny door. Ever since I was a child, I always imagined an entry into another imaginary world better than my own. And for some reason that gets fulfilled in this movie. Even though it does later get revealed that, that imaginary world is a trap. 

Now that I'm much older, I can also see why this movie still captures the attention of an older audience. Not only does it take you back to your childhood where you once imagined a better world than yours where your parents said yes to everything you ever wanted and paid more attention to you. But it also helps you realize that at the end of the day, no matter how much we wished that imaginary world existed, unfortunately it does not. And that really, it's better to not take for granted what we do have and be appreciative of it because you never know when it can be taken away from you. Just a wonderful movie and I highly recommend it!!

‘Coraline’ is simply one of the best-animated films ever made: The plot is brilliantly developed, the animation is detailed and beautiful to look at, the characters are fascinating, and the world created by Neil Gaiman and Henry Selick it's simply captivating but mysterious and dangerous and well. Influenced by ‘Alice in Wonderland,’ ‘Coraline’ is charming and macabre at the same time: At first, ‘The Other World’ seems like a dream come true, but there is also a constant sense of danger in the air. Dakota Fanning makes great work as the main character, and Teri Hatcher is flawless in her role of the Mother (And the Other Mother as well) of Coraline, not to mention the excellent performance of Keith David as the cat. ‘Coraline’ is one of the best movies of recent years, and it is the best movie by Henry Selick as a director since ‘The Nightmare Before Christmas.’

At first glance this movie is admittedly creepy, but once the viewer looks deeper, there are so many hidden details and foreshadowing clues that make the story that much more compelling. The incredible stop motion, the voice acting, the relatable idea of "the grass is always greener on the other side," and the mysterious nature of Coraline's environment makes viewing the film extremely worth it, and this creative and unique movie is one of my favorites.

This magical film is a wholly absorbing fantasy adventure. Henry Selick's dark children's tale is a rare treat for filmgoers--a stop-motion animated movie. In a time when slick 3D computer animated family films with pop culture references and poop jokes dominate the marketplace, this film is a breath of fresh air. Selick also did 'The Nightmare Before Christmas' and 'James and the Giant Peach,' so he is well-versed in the stop-motion process. He creates a vivid and endlessly inventive visual feast, a world entirely all its own. His art design, cinematography (this is the first feature film ever shot with 3-D cameras), and delightful score help paint a world we wouldn't mind getting lost in. The visuals are so dense you may need to revisit the film two or three more times to catch every little detail. The voice cast, from Dakota Fanning to Keith David, Ian McShane, and Teri Hatcher, is perfect. The story is peppered with wit and whimsy and a message about appreciating the good things in your life--friends and family. It may a little too scary and dark for the most sensitive of young viewers. But kids and adult lovers of film should fall into this fantasy, hoping never to leave. A glorious animated film

Coralline for me is one of the most scariest movie I have ever seen — no joke! I remember seeing this a year ago and loving it but being very scared of the whole thing. By the time I saw this again (June 24th 2021) this would be my third time seeing it and I am still scared. The whole plot for Coraline is chilling enough. But it gets even more scarier near the end — that is where it always gets me with the scares!! If we ignore the scary moments, I greatly enjoy this film quite a bit. The plot is interesting, the voicing for the characters were amazing, and this movie I have to admit is detailed. Everything about this film is great and fun to see, but when it comes to the scariness is where it's strong suit comes in hard. I am 16 years old logging this previous film I have nearly seen a year ago, and I still kind of refuse to see this film because of how scary it is! You would think a 16 year old who has seen some R-rated horror films would get over this movie, but nope! The first time I saw this I was scarred for like 2 days from this film and how freaking scary it was. I couldn't think of anything else but this film. I moved on — my second time wasn't as bad but I was still scared of this movie. My third time I think I handled it more like a pro but I was still scared. I haven't seen it for my fourth time but I should! Just to see if this movie gets me again with the scares. I know this is just a simple kid's film but man it is very effective on getting me scared out of my pants. If I was comparing this to A Quiet Place I would say this was scarier because A Quiet Place just left me on the edge of my seat, this movie on the other hand just scares my pants off!! I love this film, but yet I am too scared too take a dive a 4th time seeing this — foolish I know but it is just one of those movies that just gets with me with the scares!

"Coraline" was such an imaginative and terrifying film that was based off of Neil Gaiman's famous children's book of the same name and this was one of the few films where I actually read the book first!  The animation in this movie was spectacular as there are lots of creepy imagery going on here with Coraline going to the other world and discovering that the other world is not as beautiful and exciting as she thinks it is.  I also really liked the characters themselves, especially Coraline, who seems like a relatable character who has to deal with her parents being so busy all the time and she is often frustrated by this.  Another character that I really liked was the Other Mother herself as she is quite a terrifying character who tries to give Coraline lots of love and things that Coraline wants, while planning to eat her.  The only issues that I have with this film are that the beginning of the movie was a bit too slow and there were some changes from the book, like the Other Father, that I didn't care for.  Overall, "Coraline" is a treat to behold and if you love watching scary animated films or you're a huge fan of Neil Gaiman's works, then you'll definitely enjoy this movie!

As many of the stop motion films directed by Henry Selick, the rigorous effort made by Lanka studios to add a mysterious, unnerving, yet climactic film is evident. The plot, based on Neil Gaiman's graphic novel of the same title is a beautiful adaptation, which while having a PG rating, keeps even adult audiences on their seat. The incredibly detailed scenery, captivating soundtrack, and the heart warming essay skilfully adapts the tone of Gaiman's graphic novel, while adding Selick's signature style creates a unique take on the plot. The choice of voice actors, Dakota Fanning to voice Coraline and Keith David to voice the cat in particular, made the film captivating, and once again solidified Selick's efforts in the successful adaptation of the plot.

Coraline is yet another aesthetically pleasing, eerie brainchild from stop motion mastermind Henry Selick. In the film, a curious eleven-year-old named Coraline moves into a strange palace with her neglectful parents. When Coraline wanders into a mysterious parallel world through a little door, she receives all of the love and attention she thought she desired, from her "other" parents. Coraline slowly comes to realize that the other world is a TRAP, and that she has to be clever if she wants to escape alive... With a premise this interesting, you'd have to bring some top notch visuals to the table. And let me tell you, Selick DOES NOT DISAPPOINT. For a family film, the imagery is very creepy at times, but the animation style is so clean and sharp. Having read it in part, I can say that Coraline's screenplay is exceptional. Nearly every single detail written on paper translated well to film... But Bruno Coulais's riveting score will not be overlooked. Not will the talented voice cast... Years of hard work were put into making this film and the result is a wildly entertaining roller coaster ride, animated beautifully. If you're partial to creepy stop motion films and you haven't seen THIS one, literally what are you doing?? 91%!

A triumph of animation with the elements of a Grimm fairytale and a ghost story wrapped into one. Real parents be warned, Coraline is honestly too dark for a PG rating. I first saw it when I was about 12 and had nightmares for weeks.  That said, I did come back for more and give it this 5 star rating. Coraline is more nuanced, better visually planned, and more physiologically rooted than any supernatural adult horror piece I've seen. Fraud's ‘consuming mother' archetype is explored in a bizarre context as the film draws horror and suspense from a narrative centered around control and confinement (both literal and emotional). The other world is a delicious inversion of reality's honest monotony; it's more uncanny and rotten than Alice's Wonderland ever was and more fun too. 
Coraline is also refreshing in that it breaks regular child/young adult adventure narrative structures. It's nice to find a movie that understands how boring and restricting the limited freedom of youth can be rather than striving to capture "the magic of childhood". The other world and its dangers neither represent adulthood nor serve to mature and develop Coraline into a fully realized heroin. She is already brave, clever, and confident from the start. Her adventure changes how she contextualizes her world and relates to others rather than developing new traits she was lacking. She learns the classic lesson ‘be careful what you wish for' in terms of wishing to change other people. Customizing neighbors, friends, and even family is a moral door best left closed.

My friends had told me that Coraline was a classic and that I needed to see it, and as someone who doesn't really enjoy watching movies I was skeptical, but I was pleasantly surprised. I thought the story line was really enjoyable and I liked the different characters. I think my favorite relationship throughout the entire movie was between Coraline and Wylie because you could see how they grew as friends. The basic plot line was interesting because it deals with a parallel universe, but Coraline was only able to enter under certain circumstances. It gave Coraline a comforting home, basically a dream land each night, yet each morning she ended back in her own boring home. All of this was to trick her into hurting herself and her family. The stop motion and screenplay was done nicely throughout the movie and I think the music breaks were nice comic relief considering this is a children's movie and some of the scenes are a bit disturbing. The movie also teaches a great lesson of "be careful what you wish for" because Coraline thought she was now living in an amazing dream world, but as many would say it was too good to be true. Overall, I thought the movie was really good with a lot of surprising plot twists that kept my attention, and I think everyone should give this movie a chance!

But there's an element of wander and beauty that hides behind the ordinary, in a dark way in the other mother's realm, but the ending provoked reverse feelings. This movie shows that while beautiful, performative gestures draw attention and garner adoration, there is something to be said for the deep familial bonds that are formed from living an ordinary life and all the mishaps that come along with it. I really wish more movies would follow this simple and great movie structure.  Instead of a typical 3-act structure (not that it isn't technically there), the story is much closer to that of a video game.

You have a standard introductory act, but the rest of the movie is split into video game-esque "levels" that develop and unlock as Coraline makes new discoveries and completes different sections of the "map" / house.

There is a lot of messaging here as well, mostly concerning relationships between children and parents and how to navigate those in regard to real life events, but everything is "do not tell" levels of subtle so it's not in your face at all.

The Beldam itself is a magnificent creation of a "thing that bumps in the night" style of monster.  While there is a lot left unexplained, there is plenty that is exampled about the Beldam and her world.

The movie also reminds me a lot of "The Wizard of Oz" in a few different ways so its good that there are family friendly movies of this quality that make vague callbacks to classic movies.

Coraline (dir. Henry Selick) is a movie often nostalgically referred to as Halloween season arrives each year. Coraline tells the story of a girl who must save herself and her parents from the danger of an evil witch. An impressive feat of stop-motion animation and visually stunning, Coraline is often remembered for it's creepy and strange atmosphere, which is set up from the very opening sequence. The sequence is accompanied by an eerie Bruno Coulais score (Dreaming being the one used in the opening) where what the audience will come to realize is the Other Mother/Beldam creating the Coraline doll that spies on our main character and her family. This opening sequence does well in setting the tone for the rest of the film, as it provides an unsettling feeling through the surgical-like sewing, long spindly hands, and haunting score that lingers even when it's over. Coraline and her parents---an eccentric father and stricter mother---have moved to what's referred to throughout the film as the Pink Palace (short for Pink Palace apartments) in Oregon. Coraline is quite quickly shown to be an adventurous and curious girl who is frustrated at the lack of attention from her parents and what she sees as a ‘boring life'. She is often seen repeatedly complaining at different points in the film of all the other characters ‘not listening to her'.

In comes the Other Place. Coraline discovers a door while exploring the house that leads to another world that replicates her own, but with a few key differences One, the house and the atmosphere is much brighter. While her ‘real home' is colored with dull tones and lots of shades of greys, the Other Place is colorful and applies more cozy colors, such as shades of reds, purples, blues and oranges. Two, her parents are much more attentive in this world, much more doting and loving, with her Other Father a talented musician and her mother who always cooks delicious meals for her, provides her with everything she wants---but they have buttons for eyes (as do all the other characters in the Other Place). She soon realizes with the help of a talking Cat and the more she spends time in the Other Place that something is wrong, and discovers that her doppelganger mother wants to ‘consume her life' as she did with three other children.

Throughout the film, I found myself being reminded of Guillermo del Toro's Pan's Labyrinth, mostly the door that leads to another, more wondrous (appearing) world. Both films have a dark and creepy atmosphere (though arguably Pan's Labyrinth more extremely so) and employ a female protagonist who wishes to escape to a fantasy world where they believe they'll be happier. The talking Cat in Coraline shares a similar whimsical quality to Alice in Wonderland's Cheshire Cat, with its guiding nature and habitual practice of coming and going whenever it pleases. These intertextual references, though possibly unintentional, only enrich the entertaining story. It is fast-paced and witty, with the creepiness doing well to bring forth a child-like fear that even adults can remember, and concludes with a satisfying ending that brightens up the real world and Coraline's life.

This movie "Coraline" recently became available on Netflix so I gave it a go when a friend of mine said she likes and I may too if I had liked "Nightmare before Christmas" and "Corpse Bride".  I didn't like "Coraline".  I didn't get the messages the film was sending very well.  And I figure if they'd go through so much trouble as to make the film engine stop-motion, the story would be tidier and the messages more direct.  It is an Alice in Wonderland story about  rude girl who goes on a psychedelic adventure which should result in having her become a better person. Not sure if it did that for Coraline.  What is unique about this film is that the subtext message is a cautionary tale about child predators, as that is what the villain essentially is.  If it were better delivered, it would have been brilliant to me.  Nothing wrong about teaching children about that, in fact they should be taught about that.  I was put off by things meant to be humorous [there is a stage play with scantily-clad women] and scary [the villain had already been feeding off the life-essence of three children prior to trying to do the same to Coraline, but like I said that's not too disturbing given the message].  I was disturbed by Coraline not having much character growth in terms of her kindness.  But she is a determined and tenacious character worth looking up to in that sense.  I was unnerved by her family dynamic - she has neglectful parents who seem to have issues with one another too.  Should that be excused because the parents were under stress?  - They could have lost their daughter during that time.  If the message was that family members should be kinder and gentler toward each other, I wish - I really wish it would have been clearer.

Released in 2009, this cinematic masterpiece took so many artistic risks and added a dark edge. With an immensely captivating plot and gorgeous visuals, the story was truly ahead of its time. Coraline Jones is exploring her new house when she finds a secret door that leads to a parallel universe. Just when she thinks everything is alright, her Other Mother tries to persuade her to sew buttons on her eyes and stay forever. When Coraline refuses, the Other Mother goes after both of her real parents. Adapted from the 2002 children's novel by Neil Gaiman, the film includes actress Dakota Fanning voicing Coraline and Teri Hatcher voicing both the real and Other Mother. The film is far from a positive Disney production. Though Coralineï¿ 1/2(TM)s animations mainly attract children and teenagers, the film is more than appropriate for a mature audience.

Have you ever watched a children's movie that gave you the creeps? Or made your skin crawl at the thought of your mother taking your eyes? I want you to imagine your mother and father with button eyes and your life seems to be the opposite all because you went through a hole in the wall. You start to love it until your mother offers your own set of button eyes on your birthday. Thanks to the amazing and creative director of Coraline, Henry Selick, you can watch a movie about an adventurous young girl, who finds a hole in the wall and decides to explore. When she crawls through it she finds her life but a little different and peculiar. Into the Darkness

   Coraline is the most outstanding movie Henry Selick has directed. Along with the mastermind of Neil Gaiman, both of these individuals have created a frightening eerie illusion for young adolescents. The film, of course, is grouped into "children-family movies" on Netflix and the recommended age is 8-10, now if you have seen this film you would agree to disagree by a long shot. Henry Selick also directed, The Nightmare Before Christmas, which have similar characteristics that come with the visuals and sounds that are used throughout these two films. Now if you know the 3D computer-animated fantasy film, Coco, you soon realize they have a familiar plot story; a young adolescent gets warped into another universe and discovers an entryway that will cause them complex obstacles throughout the movie. Now, Coraline goes through the same scenario but you quickly discover she goes to the other universe quite frequently and leads her to immense danger.

The opening credits show needle-shaped hands grabbing a doll that has button eyes, the metal hands then continue to take apart the doll and make a unique doll which we later find out it was made for Coraline. The spine-chilling film takes place in a very gloomy city and is constantly raining. Dull colors are dominant in every scene the first 20 minutes of the film. As Coraline discovers the secret passage that leads her to the parallel universe, she meets her "other parents." Comparing and contrasting these characters, Coraline's father, is constantly working hard and has a long neck that looks similar to a footlong sandwich from subway, his features are rather asymmetrical and carries these blue-purple undereye bags that lead to him having droopy eyelids while on the other side he has a bright personality and enjoys the same activities Coraline is interested in. These frightful characteristics that the characters bring in every scene are very daunting and make you feel intimidated by the way they interact with each other as well every action they do.

Much like The Nightmare Before Christmas, the ominous setting takes place in a daunting and scary feel like due to the lack of bright visuals. They use stitched up features for the characters as well as masks and Halloween related makeup, audios, and visuals. Her upstairs neighbor is an odd Russian acrobat who claims to have trained mice and her downstairs neighbors are two elderly women who are burlesque dancers. In the other universe, they are transformed into younger versions of themselves with a more amusing personality and do enjoyable entertainments for Coraline and Wybie, her friend. The most frightening thing about these characters you may ask? Well in the other universe when Coraline's "other mother" asks her to complete complex tasks to gain her parents back ( The other mother stole her parents so Coraline could trade in her eyes for button eyes) she has to go to her upstairs neighbors home and also downstairs. First, she goes upstairs, where her Russian neighbor resides and finds that he has no head attached to his body, nor arms and legs. Mice are maneuvering every action he makes and has nobody structure, he slides throughout the room like a human snake to get from one point of the room to another. He continues to talk in a low-deep slow voice that sounds rather intimidating. At the beginning of the film, you would've never guessed how oddly these characters would get distorted.

As she progresses onto her neighbors downstairs, the burlesque dancers, there is a giant candy shaped ball wrapped in white paper hanging from the ceiling. Coraline comes in and rips open the package and the two dancers come out wrapped around each other, they look lifeless and have facial expressions that seem like they had suffered. And you know what is the scariest part? Their limbs are weaved in together making them inseparable but Coraline has to unweave them to get to the item that is necessary for their parents to escape the hands of the "other mother". What made me startle and jump in my seat was the fact that they came back to life miraculously and make a sharp sudden drop in the music and screeching of the creatures! I was already on my toes when she first walked in and saw the giant candy shaped ball.

When Coraline wins the game and returns back to her starting point, the "other mother" is waiting for her return. She is sitting in the living room eating BEETLES! She bites the head of the beetle and you can see the muscle tissue on the beetle start to spaz. As Coraline continues to say no to the button eyes, the other mother quickly gets infuriated by her decision, she becomes to transform into a bony structure that makes her unrecognizable and resembles a long tall skeleton. The reason she goes through this journey is to find the eyes of the children that the other mother had taken. The eyes represent the souls of the children that were taken from the other mother. She finds her parents trapped in a snowglobe before departing from the other universe! YAY!

As you can tell by this point of my review, I really enjoy this movie. If you enjoy creepy, spooky eerie films that make you feel tingly skin and spine-chilling entertainment, you will love this movie! Along with similar films such as The Nightmare Before Christmas. You won't be disappointed when you sit down and watch this film expecting it to be a children's movie when in reality it will scare them to the point where they won't watch to watch it ever again! So it's a win-win situation. A life lesson and good entertainment for the win!

Director Henry Selick did it again with Coraline (2009) thanks to his innovative mastery of animated direction. Selick gave us James and the Giant Peach as well as The Nightmare Before Christmas and Coraline is just a brilliant. Coraline is a fast paced short horror film for children essentially. It brings lush colors and creepy visuals together for a unique cinematic experience totally its own.

I must mention the sheer amount of detail put into each character's design and costumes. The knit clothes and fluid movements make the animation in Coraline top tier. This is as impressive as claymation gets in my opinion.

Coraline's wonderful story is written by the genius author Neil Gaiman and Coraline is another one of his great works. The writing is very funny, sarcastic, and clever. From the numerous omens alongside the setups and payoffs work great on camera. Gaiman's themes range from family and longing to disappointment and expectations. The moral is simply to appreciate what you have and be careful what you wish for, but Coraline goes about this concept in a visually sublime way.

The few musical numbers really stand out as the overall tone is like a rainy day spent at home. I love the vocals talents of Dakota Fanning, Ian McShane, Keith David, and especially Teri Hatcher. Hatcher pulls off multiple characters and every emotion you can think of displayed solely through her voice acting. Coraline has a great voice cast who all bring more charm to these odd, but lovable characters.

In all, Coraline is wonderful for families to watch together, but I think even adults would find something to enjoy. Coraline puts life into perspective with all its quaint warmth and scary chills.

I will admit, this is a FANTASTIC movie in terms of animation, story line, etc. but please, DO NOT WATCH THIS WITH CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 12 OR IN AN APARTMENT ALL ALONE! I have had nightmares the past three nights about a lady trying to sew buttons into my eyes in order to take my soul and that's quite insane coming from someone who LIVES AND BREATHES FOR HORROR AND SCARY MOVIES. It's creepy and not suitable to young or sensitive children.

Coraline is a dark fantasy claymation film that was released in 2009. It made a total of 35.6 million at the box office. It follows the story of Coraline, a young girl just moved to a new town. With no friends, and parents who pay no attention to her, she longs for a world where she is loved. After finding a secret door in her home, it transports her to a world where "Everything's better... but it's all a trap." Although it is rated PG, most do not consider it a suitable movie for children. This has caused some controversy over the movie, causing people to dislike it. However, the purpose of this essay is to show that coraline is a well made film because of its unique characters, meaningful theme, and it's animation. 
Part of what makes "Coraline" such a good movie is the characters. There are so many unique and interesting characters in this story. Coraline, for example, is far from your everage eleven-year-old girl portrayed in film. Roger Ebert explains in his movie review of the movie that, "She's unpleasant, complains, and has an attitude". It is refreshing to see a contrast from the happy-go-lucky little girl that most films portray. Another great character, frightening as she is, is the Other Mother, also known as the Beldam. Ebert states that, "'Coraline' is disturbing not for gory images but for the story it tells. That's rare in itself: Lots of movies are good at severing limbs, but few at telling tales that can grab us down inside where it's dark and scary." It takes a very well made character to be so terrifying without falling back on the use of gore. A lot of skill is required to create such dimensional and interesting characters, and they are what help bring this story to life. 
	The theme "Be careful what you wish for" is shown through the startling film, as Coraline soon realises that this "magic world" she wished for is anything but a paradise. Although Coraline's life could be better, she lives in a good home, with all the basic necessities, and her life could certainly be worse. Wishing for this utopian world where everyone worships her is what brought the curse of the Beldham upon her. By the time that she realizes that she wants no part of this sinister world, it is too late, and the Beldham has her in her trap. Not wanting to become one of the Other Mother's "dolls", she makes a deal with her and is able to save herself, her parents, and the lost souls that had been imprisoned. Not only is this film able to show the theme in a striking way, but it is also able to be resolved to give viewers a sense of conclusion. 
	Anyone who has viewed this film can concede to the fact that "Coraline" has beautiful animation. After 83 weeks of filming, this stop motion claymation film was brought to life. Being the first film of its kind to be offered in 3d, it took a even deeper step to pull viewers into this dark world. Not only is the cinematography aesthetically pleasing to watch, but it helps set the mood of the entire film. Every scene helps bring about the gloomy, uneasiness of the film. Even in scenes where the other world is made up to be a bright, beautiful place, the style and animation make it hard to trust that this place is truly harmless. It is easy to observe all the hard work put into making this film what it truly is - a masterpiece. With years in pre-production and filming, it is difficult to not be in awe at every scene. 
	On the other hand, some people say that "Coraline" is a bad film because it is scary, and marketed as a children's film. This point of view makes sense because the film is rated PG, and it is quite terrifying at times. However, the official genre of  "Coraline"is a fantasy thriller. In the rating it says that there are frightening images. Parents should be well aware of what kind of movie they are having their children watch, and know their child well enough to know whether or not they would be able to handle the content in the film. A. O. Scott explains in his review of the film that, "the cultivation of fright can be one of the great pleasures of youthful moviegoing." Many children enjoy a bit of a scare, so it is unfair to judge a film based on the ignorance of parents. 
There are many elements of 'Coraline" that make it such a great movie. The characters are very unique, and make the story interesting. The theme holds a good lesson and is portrayed through the film very well. The animation helps show the mood of this film, and makes it aesthetically pleasing. It is important that we give "Coraline" the credit it deserves, instead of just blindly assuming that it is a bad film. It is important to make decisions for ourselves, and go into anything - movies, classes, etc - with an open mind. Otherwise, you may miss out on something very extraordinary.

Strengths: What a gorgeous looking movie. The stop-motion animation is done incredibly well here. Everything just looks so great. The story is also great, with the right amount of twists and buildup. Things get progressively more creepy as it unfolds. The film does a tremendous job in balancing the scary with the fun for the kids. I'm sure the comparison has come up before, but I kept getting The Nightmare Before Christmas vibes. Coraline (Dakota Fanning) is a strong, flawed lead and her relationship with the Cat (Keith David) was a highlight. There's also a well-crafted family message at the end of it all.

Weaknesses: One issue I had was that the antagonist (Teri Hatcher) didn't quite feel like a great villain. I'm not sure what I'd have added to improve that off the top of my head, it's just something that could've been done better. While I feel Coraline is a strong lead, I wouldn't call her likable. She has several moments where she attempts to be funny or quirky, but comes across as kind of mean towards the boy in town. I don't know how to put my finger on it, but something about this movie didn't completely enthrall and engage me quite the way the top animated films I've ever seen have.

Overall: This is a very good, just not great film. The animation and story are both damn good, it just never reaches the heights of the best animated features I've seen.

"Coraline" is a 100 minute 3D stop-motion, dark fantasy horror film released on February 5, 2009 and it is based on Neil Gaiman's novel, "Coraline". This film was directed and produced by Henry Selick and also produced by Claire Jennings, Bill Mechanic and Mary Sandell.
The movie was released on the US on February 6, 2009, making 16 million during the opening weekend and 124 million worldwide. This production gained a large number of awards like "Annie Awards", "Academy Awards" and a "Golden Globe" nomination.	
The film is based on a girl who recently moved to a new house in Oregon. Coraline has typical family problems where parents are too occupied for their children, and that makes her sad, lonely and frustrated. By feeling this way, she starts exploring her new house trying to find something fun in addition to her neighbors. In all of this situation, Caroline is being watched  by an evil and hungry witch by means of a doll that looks exactly like Caroline but with button eyes.
 As the movie goes on, she finds a mysterious key and starts visiting a "perfect" parallel world in her "dreams", where everything is what she has always wanted. But there were some sort of things that were very strange and dark in this new world, so she starts questioning things. When she finally got some answers from three dead kids, she starts to plan her scape doing everything she can  and turning into a menace to the witch. In order to get rid of that world she needs to pass a lot of tests and hard work, because if not, she would be stuck in it forever and the evil witch will feed on her for the rest of her life. At this point she understand how much her real family means to her despite every problem and that she would give her all to get her parents back. This motivation gives Coraline a touch of strength, and with the help of some friends she starts this horrendous adventure. 
The footage in this movie is amazing. It takes the stop-motion to whole new level, using 3D printers and having different parts of just one character body to make everything more realistic. The film involved 450 people to help with the project, including all types of professionals. Another thing that makes the movie environment is the stunning music performed by Michele Marina, John Linnel, Kent Melton and Bruno Coulais.
In my personal opinion this is a tremendous movie not only because the spectacular footage but because of the amazing lesson and its way to show it. One of them is the reality that we are living now days, were parents don't have enough time for their kids because they have other priorities, causing a worrisome impact on kids, and leading them to a rebel status or to do dangerous things without their parents noticing because they aren't present. But also it let the kids to understand that their parents do love them despite they are always present or not and try to understand that they are working for the future of the family. Another moral the movie shares, is the importance of valuing the things we already have and to love our family the way it is. To not get blinded by material things, because at the end it is what it is, material. 
It is a story where all kind of audience can get identified and it attracts a lot of people of different ages. Even though it looks like a children movie it isn't that innocent or sane as it looks. The movie could be a little traumatic for some kind of minor audience because it has very impacting scenes. This quality is a very distinctive one, because usually cartoon movies or this types of films where there are no actors, can lead us to automatically think that this is just another kids movie, which can be a good and a bad thing. A good one because the adult audience can get interested in the film and they can talk about it to others and gain viewers. And a bad thing because parents can take their little kids to watch it, thinking it won't scare them. Of course everybody reacts different and there are kids who totally love the film. 
The end of the movie can make us feel that a sequel can come out of it. The film let to our imagination what finally happened with certain things that were obviously unconcluded. They can make a second movie and it would have a lot of success if it come like the first one or even  better. But of course, the making of a movie like that isn't totally easy and it takes years to complete it, so lets hope for a sequel in an near future.

Coraline is a movie about a girl named Coraline who moves into a strange community to 
find out that the people who live next door are even stranger. After moving into the new apartment her parents work on a gardening catalogue and seem to never have time for her making food or even cleaning the place. Coraline then meets wybie a boy who apparently will never keep his mouth shut, Mr Bobinski a russian mouse circus trainer, Miriam Forcible, and Apryl Spink.

        As i mentioned before, her parents didn't really have time for her so she had to find her own way of having fun. After waking up in the middle of the night coraline is surprised by a mouse and decides to chase it down the stairs and into the family room to find a slot in the wall almost like a forbidden little door. She eneters it and sees that her mother is there and so is her father but something is off about them her father suddenly learned to play the piano and is no longer busy with work and her mother is making her favourite food and being the nicest person to her. They call her caroline as if they are her parents but then she realizes that they have buttons for eyes. 

 	The next morning she wakes up and notices that it was all a dream because once she gets downstairs her parents and back to treating her like a bag of rubbish. After her visit to bobinskis wybie gives coraline a doll that looks exactly like her but instead has buttons for eyes. Coraline takes the doll not thinking anything of it and goes home, that night she goes to sleep again and is much happier to be back because not only are the second parent's nice but everything else also better than the real world after enjoying her time the second mom asks her to join them forever but coraline disagrees which then leads to a series of horrible events such as kidnapping sewing wybie's mouth together and a lot of other strange things.


	After trying to escape that crazy world coraline is then surprised when her cat starts talking to hert and tells her that the second mother is actually a woman who kidnaps children and eats them caroline tries to run but mother catches her and puts her into a prison after seeing the ghost of the other children coraline realizes her parents are missing so she makes a deal with mother 2 and says that if she finds her parents that she must let all the souls and her parents go and if not she will stay with her.

	All in All she finds them and then returns to her original world and finds out it was all a dream and her parents were just out shopping, she runs to them with joy to find out the good news that the gardening catalogue was good and her parents start to care for her. I do enjoy the plot but in my  opinion the art and characters are a little weird and creepy. Numerous times the movie had a dark tone to it which made me not like it as much as i could have.

Since the Brothers Grimm penned their morbid fairy tales (and probably before), children and adults have escaped into fantasy to safely explore the dangers of reality. Tales such as Hansel and Gretel, and in the last century The Wizard of Oz, have provided imaginative worlds with dangers at every turn. The purpose of such tales was always to warn, educate, and provide a backdrop for moral instruction.

Such is true of Coraline, a cinematic fairy tale crafted by writer Neil Gaiman and director Henry Selick (The Nightmare Before Christmas). Based on a book by Gaiman, this visually astounding stop-motion masterpiece is a reminder that not all fairy tales have wistful princesses and happy musical numbers (sorry, Disney). This is a return to the creepy morality tales of yore, and while young children may have nightmares from the unsettling mood and tone, older children and adults will likely delight in both its imagination and its message.

Coraline's title character is a plucky and resilient child (expertly voiced by Dakota Fanning) who has moved to a dusty, lonely old house in Washington with her parents. Both are neglectful in their own way: her father is caring enough, but is constantly aloof, while her mother (voiced by Teri Hatcher) is so busy that she hardly notices her daughter, and is often annoyed by her when she does.

One night, Coraline discovers a portal into a parallel existence: same house, same parents, but here everything is exactly as she wishes it were in reality. The dreariness of her true home is replaced by vibrant colors and spectacle. Her neglectful parents are replaced by updated versions who live only to lavish her with affection and wish-fulfillment. Soon Coraline begins to greatly prefer the alternate life to her actual one. It's all seems perfect, but she (and the audience) cannot shake the unsettling suspicion that something isn't quite right. Only a sage old black cat (who is realistically silent in the "real world," but suavely vocal in other) seems to understand the dangers behind the seductive facade of Coraline's dream world.

To say more would be to ruin the surprises, but suffice to say that the film contains excellent messages for those who look for discussion points to share with their children afterward. The dream world serves as a perfect metaphor for the cunningly disguised lies of harmful people, as well their tactics of using subtle counterfeits to grant people's wishes in the short run, while slowly entangling (and later chaining) them in the long run.

As my mother always said: "If it seems too good to be true, it probably is." With regards to Coraline's dream parents, they may be seen as a practical warning against slick strangers who might lure children away by promising them exactly what they want (much like the "candy man" character in Chitty Chitty Bang-Bang). The black cat, whose warnings initially go unheeded, may be seen to serve a similar purpose to parents, friends, and teachers. He is a wise, caring character who sees and understands things that the protagonist does not yet comprehend, tries to keep her from harm, and helps her when she is in peril.

Furthermore, the film not only reminds parents of the need to give their children attention and affection, but also helps children understand the stresses of parenting and the need for gratitude for the parents they do have.

In addition to serving as a lasting morality tale, Coraline is a terrific artistic achievement. While computer-generated animation is en vogue at the moment, the terrific and nearly seamless stop-motion animation here is something different and gorgeous to behold. The film is currently showing both in 3D and as a regular feature; I recommend that you see it in 3D if possible, as the richly designed sets and characters were meant to be experienced in that format. Far from a mere gimmick, the 3D in this case actually brings more life to the story, revealing layers and depth that were actually created by hand and filmed, one meticulous frame at a time.

Parents should be warned, that while the film contains no real violence, it is full of unsettling images and a creepy atmosphere that will doubtless give nightmares to little ones (much like the wicked witch from The Wizard of Oz, though this is a good deal scarier). There is mild profanity. A scantily-dressed and buxom elderly woman, though a clay-animated figure and far from titillating, may be offensive to some. That said, for older kids, teens, and adults who possess rich imaginations and an appreciation for this type of film, Coraline is a terrific night at the movies, and worth the added fee to view in 3D.

Plot
Coraline relocates to a new house where she soon feels ignored by her working parents.  She discovers a secret door and slips into a magical world where she meets a loving and caring 'Other mother '- things seem perfect but there is hidden danger about to unfold.

Review
This fantasy horror film is creepy, scary, unpredictable but exciting.  It takes us from the boring reality of everyday life to the charming 'other world'.

Coraline is a young, feisty, curious and courageous girl.  She gets bored with her new neighbourhood and starts to explore her surroundings.  

Her parents are too busy trying to make a living and give her little attention.  She tells them about her adventures but they don't believe her and aren't very impressed. 

Soon Coraline finds out that the 'Other mother' is evil.  She traps children, steals their eyes and stiches buttons in their place.   In an effort to save the ghost children Coraline makes a bet/plays a game with the other mother and tries to free the souls of the trapped children and her parents.

Verdict
This terrifying but interesting movie is one of the most amazing children stories of all time.

Imaginative, beautifully animated and successfully managing to start off as a nice family-friendly movie about a girl who discovers a parallel world better than the crappy one she's living in at the moment to a dark horror film about a woman hell bent on ensuring her "daughter" stays there as part of her elaborate plan, Coraline is an entertaining film that ranks among one of the best animated films of 2009...and also a great start to stop-motion animation studio Laika who following the production, but not complete involvement, of Corpse Bride seems to show themselves as a worthy competitor to British stop-motion animation studio Aardman.

The characters are also very well done and they have very realistic personality traits as well as very artistic designs. The story is very well paced as well as very well told. I always look forward to watching this movie every Halloween. (A)

The voice work was all top notch, I really liked each character and I loved how different and strange they all were. Coraline also features maybe the best villain I've ever seen in a stop motion film, and maybe even a kids film with The Other Mother, hands down one of the creepiest characters I've seen. It almost qualifies as a horror film, kids would definitely be frightened by everything happening to the main character and the weird imagery on screen. I definitely found it unnerving at times, but I wouldn't say scary, just really unsettling for a kids movie. Coraline is something unlike I've ever seen, and doubt I'll see again

Can _ANYBODY_ explain to me what the heck the movie "Coraline" is supposed to be about? 

I can't make sense of the hero's journey in the movie.  For example, there are 'rule elements' of horror films (like "The creepy kid who keeps dropping important plot clues and leaving) that get brought over only to be utterly broken (Coraline never pursues half the stuff Whybe tells her about, and so effectively he's just filler to make the movie longer?) and therefore make no sense. As a result I can't figure out why Coraline even goes on the journey, what she learns that is useful information in the real world, and how she then applies that learning to the real world. 

I want to go back in time and retroactively get up in a huff and leave the movie theater every time she calls Whybe "Why be born" -- what a little bitch! (and to the writers, did you think we weren't going to get his character's self-importance struggles from his name being "Whybe" so you had to make Coraline call him that every time?) 

I mean, movies are about life, for the most part... and when they aren't about life (or are too focused on the experience of only a few weird individuals) in some way, they're usually pretty much ignored, or just really bad and boring. 

So, I find it difficult to find any redeeming qualities of the character Coraline, and I feel really bad about that for some reason. I have so many female friends who are kind of like Coraline, and yet they don't grate on my nerves. I somehow have let the fact that I do not get this movie affect me deeply. It feels like any friend who is the slightest bit feminist will think I'm their enemy because I don't get it. 

This movie however was critically acclaimed by viewers and professional critics alike an IMDB Rating of 7.7 and a meta score of 80 as well as a Tomatometer of 90% and those kinds of scores are very hard to come by and would be only dreamed about by most filmmakers. And I just do not get it. At all.

Neil Gaiman is so contemporarily vital, both in literature and cinema, because he more than anyone else (with the possible exception of Terry Gilliam) notes that children and adults alike are fascinated with what lies outside our observable and tangible realms of existence. He realized the reasons storytelling have been significantly important since the dawn of mankind, and devised, as the Brothers Grimm did, that fairy tales and children's stories had to be haunting and entertaining to be both memorable and timeless. This is a great film depicting the growing sense as a child approaches adolescence that their parents and their world aren't exactly as they seem, and that through their trials and tribulations (the 'rites of passage', if you will) they'll reach the 'happy medium' they need to in order to find true happiness in their lifetimes.

I definitely hope that all of Gaiman's books and graphic novels are made into movies (I most anticipate the 'Miracleman' graphic novels--both those by him and Alan Moore). Ones so well-written would truly be 'comic book movies' worth watching for me.

The director of "Coraline" has suggested it is for brave children of any age. That's putting it mildly. This is nightmare fodder for children, however brave, under a certain age. I know kids are exposed to all sorts of horror films via video, but "Coraline" is disturbing not for gory images but for the story it tells. That's rare in itself: Lots of movies are good at severing limbs, but few at telling tales that can grab us down inside where it's dark and scary.

Even more rare is that Coraline Jones is not a nice little girl. She's unpleasant, complains, has an attitude and makes friends reluctantly. Nor does she meet sweet and colorful new pals in her adventure, which involves the substitution of her parents by ominous doubles with buttons sewn over their eyes. She is threatened with being trapped in their alternate world, which is reached by an alarming tunnel behind a painted-over doorway in her own.

Not that Coraline's own parents are all that great. They're busy, distracted, bickering and always hunched over their computers. They hardly hear her when she talks. That's why she recklessly enters the tunnel and finds her Other Mother and Other Father waiting with roast chicken and a forced cheerfulness. All she needs to stay there is to have buttons sewn into her own eye sockets. 

The Other Mother and Father essentially want to steal Coraline from her real but distracted parents and turn her into some kind of a Stepford daughter. 

I admire the film mostly because it is good to look at. Credit is due to those who backed this film. I'm tired of wall-to-wall cuteness like "Kung Fu Panda," and wonder if Selick's approach would be suited to films for grown-ups adapted from material like stories by August Derleth or Stephen King.

And perhaps I didn't make it clear that it's fine with me that Coraline is an unpleasant little girl. It would be cruelty to send Pippi Longstocking down that tunnel, but Coraline deserves it. Maybe she'll learn a lesson.

When it comes to animated films, they usually are sweet family oriented fables but every once in a while an animated feature that's actually more than that appears; like the orchestral musical "Fantasia", the heavy on dark themes "Hunchback of Notre Dame" or the horror film "Coraline". 
Coraline Jones is a teenager who moves from Michigan to Oregon with her parents. When she is exploring her new home she discovers a secret tunnel that leads her to another reality where everything is magical, but Coraline will soon discover that not everything is what it seems to be. 
With Henry Selick (the man that was truly the one responsible for the beloved "The Nightmare Before Christmas) at the helm of this stop motion animated film, my expectations were high and thankfully Selick didn't disappoint. "Coraline" has gorgeous stop motion animation (which is incredible for a new studio to make this high quality animation), a story that feels like "Alice in Wonderland" meets Edgar Allan Poe (to the point of combining Cheshire with Poe´s Black Cat), a mesmerizing world that will impress you with its creativity throughout the film´s running time, the pacing goes from a wonder/whimsical feel to a full on horror vibe, the voice acting is solid, some of the imagery is absolutely unforgettable, the songs aren't exactly memorable but they are creepy (exactly what they needed to be), the character designs are great even though the characters are nothing more than stereotypes, a fantastic/creepy villainess that will definitely scare children under 10, a well-made creepy Halloween atmosphere, a protagonist that isn't an annoyingly whiny girl neither a goody two shoes heroine, the character development is predictable but it works within this film, a beautiful message, and it has a more than appropriate running time. My big issue with the film is that the fantastic world works so perfectly that you almost forget about the reality setting as it never has a memorable scene and it's an element that comes and goes because it only is here as setup for the fantasy realm of the film (Kind of what happened in "Inside Out", you spend so much time in the creatively beautiful setup that when you return to the real world of the film it comes off as a wasted opportunity of making a memorable setup like Guillermo Del Toro did in "Pan´s Labyrinth").
"Coraline" is a beautiful animated film that has the wonder feel of "Nightmare" plus a horror vibe. It is definitely a perfect horror movie for children (it will give them nightmares to kids that are under the age of 10) and one of the best -if not the best- stop motion animated feature films ever made (Tim Burton needs to learn a few things from this film)

A creepy, twisted, fantasy horror film.  The movie starts off pretty slow but then gets pretty quick when the suspense kicks in and the frightening things start happening.  The Movie has a pretty dark surrounding for kids but still kind of scary for mature people. This movie has a pretty scary soundtrack and the ending was really good. Coraline is a beautifully dark and alluringly peculiar picture with wonderful animation, well-developed characters, and a message that speaks on the importance of coping with reality rather than falling victim to the dangers of reality-destroying fantasy. The picture boasts an excellent voice cast on top of its gorgeous visuals and pertinent themes, and while it may not be the film small children will play on a loop with every waking hour, it's a must-see picture for mature viewers of all ages, particularly those who will be able to understand its themes within the context of the bleak visual picture it paints.
It's not quite as enchanting as "The Nightmare Before Christmas," but that might be setting the bar a little high. It's still very imaginative and beautifully animated.
Credit must go to every skilled animator and technician involved in the dazzling creation of Coraline, which stews in an atmosphere that's eerie, magnificently bizarre, and made with care.

What it lacks in humor it compensates with creativity and visual dazzle; what it misses in the storytelling department it makes up with a spooky and unique atmosphere. Stunning, detailed and downright impressive in a techincal point of view; Coraline is an undoubtedly rewarding stop-motion gem.

Charming to the last, Coraline was a fresh escape from the regular world of 3D animated movies for me. Loved the way stop-motion animation was used to narrate such a vivid world, with spontaneous character development and lucid storyline. Coraline's character as a headstrong, tomboyish girl with her acute sense of curiosity and adventurousness carries the movie forward, it was such a joy to watch her throughout the whole story. While the story is a familiar 'child finds secret door and hidden world behind it', it is hard to argue about how well composed it was. Coraline's quest to find the missing eyes and her parents was enthralling on its own, arguably akin to playing a great adventure role playing game. Name of movie: Coraline
Director: Henry Selick 
Genre: Animation/Fantasy
Rating: 3.5 Stars

Intro: This film is for an audience of thrill seeking movie watchers. The movie looks as if it was made by Tim Berton but with a little uniqueness 
slipped in. The story is very intriguing the whole time and never looses you. This movie is all about the adventures of Coraline a girl who moves into a 
mysterious house that holds many secrets. I would advise parents that this movie has scenes that could be scary to kids that are under the age of 
seven.

Summary of the Movie.:
The movie Coraline is a story about a young girl that moves to an old house called "The Pink Palace" and finds a secret that is centuries long. After 
moving away from her home in Michigan she starts to feel alone. She feels that her parents don't care about her so she looks for some entertainment. 
She finds a small door that has been locked and bricked up. But during the night she is drawn to the small door to see that it connects to an other 
world. This world has everything she wanted to be in her past life. But her parents and everything she has ever known has a twist on it because they 
all have button eyes. After a wile of seeing how amazing this "other world" is she gets obsessed. Until her "other mother" wishes for her to stay there 
forever but Coraline refuses and tries to leave. With no luck she has to trick her "other mother" to letting her go back to her old life. 

Theme: The theme of Coraline is to be carful what you wish for. This movie teaches you that you should love what you have and never wish to 
change your family. Henry was trying to connect to kids that want another mother or sister or brother to make there life "better".

Technical Elements: The movie Coraline is all claymation. Some parts may look animated but it is claymation. In other words it is stop motion which 
means it's a bunch of pictures taken every time a clay prop moves the slightest. Then if it is played back it makes motion.

Conclusion: Over all Coraline is a really good movie but can be scary to young viewers. I would certainly recommend this to a family that wants to 
have a movie night. Coraline is an amazing movie and takes you on an journey through your wildest imaginations. Henry based this movie on a book 
written by Neil Gaimen, the two stories are basically the same story but with a little twist on the movie. Clearly this movie is a must watch for any 
family and is a movie you will never forget.

Laika's first film and my favorite of theirs. This is one of the coolest and most interesting stories I've seen in a while and, thanks to Henry Selick's incredible direction, it's just filled to the brim with atmosphere and chills that'll get you hooked from the very first shot. It is also one of the few American animated features that does not try to be a comedy. Think about that. That's how one dimensional we are when it comes to animation. It's also is one of the rare instances where seeing the movie had me wanting to read the book. Anyway, go watch it. It's pretty amazing.

Coraline explores the boundaries of what is appropriate to be put in a children's movie. Thanks to the chilling atmosphere the traditional plot and pace is replaced with a very original storytelling technique. This movie shows what kind of power and impact stop-motion animation can have have in the entertainment world of the silver screen.Being the first movie to come out of LAIKA, Coraline sets a very high standard and expectancy for future masterpieces  like it.

Coralline is directed and written by Henry Selick, and it stars Dakota Fanning in a stop-motion film about a girl who doesn't like moving to another place, and she come across a room that's locked, and when she goes in, she come across a different place that's similar, and the families that have button for eyes. After watching Aladdin, the bus started to get more quiet, and we didn't watch anything else for now. So I ended up watching the downloaded films on Netflix, and just watched this first, which is a fantastic starter for Laika Studios. Dakota Fanning is great at being whiny and irritated at the same time, but it was never annoying, and she also gets better when the movie progresses. The clay-nation looks fantastic, and there were some moments that I honestly don't know how they did it. The characters are three-dimensional that when things get out of hand, you really start to root for Coraline and fear for her safety. It has a lot of creepy imagery, but it's never to the point that it'll be traumatic to kids, and it's cool to see something be pleasant, and be not so pleasant. The pacing really starts to pick up when the beginning is slow, but it still keeps you interested in what's going on. There are some humor that's really good that it doesn't really become too depressing to watch. The writing and direction by Henry Selick really seem to understand about what the kid is going through when they have to move to a different place, and just have to deal with it a different way from what the parents are going through. In the end, Coraline is an amazing film that i wish that more people could go see the films that Laika Studios has made.

For the most part, this visually stunning, stop-motion film was fun, imaginative, and entertaining, but there were some glaring issues with it that I couldn't stand.

The tropes. My god, there are so many tropes. It's a walking stereotype. This isn't to say that the movie is bad-- it isn't. It's a good movie. But when a trope hits, you know it is one, and you know exactly how it's going to play out from the beginning. For example, the sort of heavy-handed "fetch quest" revolving around the eyes of the ghost children. That whole thing felt so sappy and pointless.

Coraline's parents. For the entire first half of the film, they're awful and negligent. Then they toss in some emotionally-manipulating scene where Coraline's mother tries to act nice out of completely nowhere, leaving me baffled at the lack of continuity in the character. It was put in for the sole purpose of making you feel like Coraline would still be "better off" with her real family than in the other dimension.

The villain. I felt SORRY for her. I felt even more sorry for the villain than I did Coraline's parents. It's obvious they tried as hard as ever to make her "evil" (again, see sappy ghost children above), but they tried to get that across by simultaneously making her out to be this lonely individual that needed love so bad that she'd stop at nothing to get it. Sure, she didn't understand what love was, but she knew she wanted it. That seemed... really, really sad to me. Maybe it was meant to be this way, but I highly doubt it.

The exposition, Deus Ex Machina cat. Don't need to elaborate on that.

I know I'm making it sound like I think the movie's awful. I don't. It was very imaginative, creative, and immersive, but unfortunately, very safe and predictable. While being enchanted by the visuals, acting, and story, I did find that it used way, WAY too many cliches. I've never read the book, so I don't know who is meant to be blamed for that.

Overall, good movie, and on its own, a little different, but don't expect anything TOO unique.

This creepy, surreal, stop-motion-animated fairy tale has a gorgeous look that is totally enchanting. Title character Coraline has just moved with her parents to a new town. A small door in the family's new dining room, in a large house shared with other tenants, leads to a magical alternate universe where everyone in Coraline's life has a duplicate, except they have buttons in their faces instead of eyes. In the other world, her parents listen to her and play with her and make wonderful food for her. It seems much nicer than the real world, but she soon discovers the wonders of the other world are lures to lead her into a trap.

The story is suitably bizarre, but it's the film's look that is astounding. Painstakingly animated using stop-motion techniques, the film's sets and models are spectacular. There is so much detail and such a unique visual style, your eyes are constantly roaming across the screen, soaking in all the little embellishments and doodads in the background. Although the story's momentum flags a bit when Coraline has to go on a treasure hunt to save herself, the sheer ingenuity on display is enough to keep you smiling until the end.

Neil Gaiman is so contemporarily vital, both in literature and cinema, because he more than anyone else (with the possible exception of Terry Gilliam) notes that children and adults alike are fascinated with what lies outside our observable and tangible realms of existence. He realized the reasons storytelling have been significantly important since the dawn of mankind, and devised, as the Brothers Grimm did, that fairy tales and children's stories had to be haunting and entertaining to be both memorable and timeless. This is a great film depicting the growing sense as a child approaches adolescence that their parents and their world aren't exactly as they seem, and that through their trials and tribulations (the 'rites of passage', if you will) they'll reach the 'happy medium' they need to in order to find true happiness in their lifetimes.

I definitely hope that all of Gaiman's books and graphic novels are made into movies (I most anticipate the 'Miracleman' graphic novels--both those by him and Alan Moore). Ones so well-written would truly be 'comic book movies' worth watching for me.

Spurred from the thrilling imagination of Neil Gaiman (and his horrific children's novel by the same name), Coraline is a pungently macabre cautionary tale about a young girl who stumbles into a parallel reality when she discovers a mysterious little door in her parent's new home. Finally, another animated film that respects the intelligence of its young audience.

Let's start 13 Days of Halloween with Coraline!

Coraline is a very atmospheric movie, it's atmospheric in its characters, its colors, its lighting and tone, and at times it's very noteworthy and likable in its own creativity. This is one of those films where I think that the stop-motion department was at its best, considering that Coraline was made by a new film company called Laika, who also did Paranorman, that's another review, but, let's take a look at what we have.

We have a busy family and their daughter Coraline Jones played by Dakota Fanning, their moving into a new dilapidated-apartment building and Coraline is simply bored because her parents are always busy and never have any time to spend with her. However, that all changes when she finds a door leading to a special world one night, in fact, it's her home simply reversed. There she encounters her "Other Mother", her mother simply with buttons for eyes. There she has the time of her life, she has great food, she's entertained but most importantly she feels like where she belongs and the more she visits the more she wants to stay. Or does she? It isn't until she realizes that the world that she's visiting isn't all hunky-dory and she realizes that she needs to escape the clutches of the Other Mother in order for her, and presumably her family, to be set free...

Let's talk at what we have here. First off, you have to take the fact that this was made by a new company called Laika who just started fresh and new. Laika, owned by the Nike philanthropist Phil Knight who doesn't seem to be the best person to give to a film company especially seeing what he does. But, it keeps the studio opened so I can't really complain.

Coraline tone color goes between warm and cold, warm and cold. And you know what, that actually makes sense since the film takes place in Oregon and I've been there before, well, Washington actually. But it's still cool nonetheless, and this film has its tone down pretty perfectly. When a characters in a house, you imagine it being warm, or when a character outside, you literally felt like it was cold. Stuff like the tone is great and I hope that Laika continues to do the same thing with its films.

The characters are very memorable. You have two old actresses that argue, you have an old man who's interested in the mice circus and is also very flexible. You have another character who gets involved who is actually very comedic. Heck, even her parents, and "other" parents do a pretty good job conveying emotion into their roles, as if you literally felt like this movie was being watched in real life, not in stop-motion. I felt that all the characters were real, I felt like the creepy imagery was real.  Oh, speaking of, at the start of the next half of the movie the imagery and the colors get dark slowly but surely and the atmosphere literally takes it time building up with the characters and their speed and pacing. And, I'm sorry, but that has to be one of the most ideal atmospheric stuff that you can put in a movie, making it good for the kids because they wanna see what happen and making it suspenseful, and good for the adults who want to see the imagery and colors of both worlds. And to be honest, I find movies like that fascinating. They give more for the kids and just enough for adults, and I have to say Neil Gaiman should be proud for writing the book and Henry Selick for trying their best (especially at the start of their own career) to make a movie so magical and so colorful...

Are there problems? None that I can find, unless you simply don't like the movie for whatever reason. The characters are likable; they're nice to listen to. I couldn't find any problems, but, I really enjoyed the movie, its heartwarming, its beautiful, its colorful, it's memorable. It's an all-around good movie well deserving of the high score and as I said before, I really enjoyed it.

With its quirkily designed characters and vintage aesthetic, Coraline is the measuring stick by which all stop-motion projects are appraised. It is a visual delight, with a deeply nostalgic innocence threading its story. Rich personalities, intelligent humor, and a genuine eerie factor lurking beneath its facade, Coraline is too much fun to just watch once.

I can hardly think of a single negative thing to say about Coraline. After enjoying ParaNorman and after a recommendation from a friend, I eagerly viewed Coraline. The movie has a great track-record with critics and intelligent people alike; and it is just as good, if not better than its reputation. So why only give it 70%? I really don't have a solid answer for that question. 

Inquisitive Coraline Jones and her family move into a run-down apartment house called the Pink Palace. Coraline's family is boring. Her life is boring. Her neighbors are eccentric and hard to connect with. And her new house is ... boring. That is, until she discovers a secret door. What during the day is a simple blocked off tunnel, becomes a magical portal to another dimension at night! And in this other dimension, her family is bubbly, her life is vivacious, her neighbors are delightful, and her house is exciting! But all that glitters is not gold, a proverb that Coraline is forced to learn the hard way.

The story is very well put together, if a bit predictable. I never felt that Coraline was in any particular danger throughout the goings on. But that doesn't negate the entertaining narrative. There isn't much humor in the script, but it's not really a serious movie either. As the story flows along, the visuals get more and more stunning. That is one of the main things I love about the plot, it provides for wonderful eye-candy!

And what delicious eye-candy it is! The visuals pop from start to finish. At the beginning, the movie has a very drab feel - to reflect how dreary Coraline's life is. Once we move into the alternate reality, we are treated to some more bright colors and flamboyant situations. But when the alternate reality turns sour, we get a haunted, gothic feel. It's all beautifully animated in the flawlessly done stop-motion. As I said in my ParaNorman review, stop-motion is a largely ignored sub-genre, but it definitely shouldn't be. 

Dakota Fanning gives a spunky performance as Coraline. The character is a fun one, but she never seems to truly get terrified. Any realistic person (no matter how old) would be thoroughly freaked out by the situation Coraline finds herself in. 

Teri Hatcher and Keith David are the only other stand-outs in the cast. Hatcher plays Coraline's mother, and the fiendish "Other Mother." While normal mother is generic and unsurprising, Other Mother is quite the opposite! It's pretty cool when the character gets all ghoulish and disgusting! Keith David plays the astute feline. It's a very fun character, and David gives him a strong voice to match.

Not to echo what I said about ParaNorman, but once again we have another example of a kids' movie that is completely inappropriate for children. I was expecting it more this time around, so it didn't affect me as much. Still, it's an issue that bugs me a little. But in this case, it doesn't lower the score.

The slip-up the filmmakers make isn't really their fault. It lies in the source material. To condense the movie, it basically goes like this (spoilers): Coraline is disappointed with her life. She doesn't particularly care for her parents. She finds a portal to another dimension. Everything is fine and dandy on the other side, making her real life seem even worse. She travels over to the fake world and realizes that it's actually a really twisted and terrible place. After much trial, she finally makes it back to the real world (spoilers over). Supposedly, through her experience, she learns that "the grass isn't always greener on the other side." But does she really? If the options are a normal life, or a sadistic witch who eats your soul, I think most everybody would choose a normal life. So if the other world was better than her real one, would Coraline have stayed there - forsaking her real family? Yes, she learns to appreciate her family, but compared to her other option; did she really learn her lesson? I think not.

On a whole, Coraline is a very well made movie. It's enjoyable for its animation and wonderful visuals. But it just simply is not my kind of movie. The Tim Burton style of filmmaking has never really appealed to me, but this movie is an exception. Not my favorite kind of movie, but one I appreciate for what it is.

"I'm Coraline Jones. I've got so much to tell you." 7/10
