"EVIL WITCH, I'M NOT SCARED!"

Stop-motion animation is something that I strongly support. Looking into the hard, heavy detail of the models and the visuals, and with Hollywood's push towards CGI, it looks like Claymation is in a state of decline. Sure there's been some hits like The Nightmare Before Christmas, Chicken Run, Wallace and Gromit, and Corpse Bride, but on top of that,  there's other that, while critically acclaimed, were massive flops, such as Fantastic Mr. Fox, Frankenweenie, and The Pirates: Band of Misfits. But there's one independent studio that just doesn't give up, and that's a small studio called Laika. With the upcoming release of The Boxtrolls and two modest successes on their hands, it looks like Laika is appealing Claymation to a new generation. While I'm definitely excited about a film about boxtrolls, it was about time that I gave watch to Laika's other films, so naturally, I started with the first, Coraline, which is based on a children's book by Neil Gaiman and directed by Henry Selick, also known for The Nightmare Before Christmas (my all-time favorite stop-motion film) and James and the Giant Peach. And I'm glad I finally decided to give Coraline a watch, as the film is visually imaginative, dark, and sometimes terrifying, and I highly enjoyed it.

Having been relocated to an old home in Oregon called The Pink Palace (which has been turned into renovated apartments), eleven-year-old Coraline Jones is bored with her life. Her parents are always busy with their work and seem to ignore her in every minute, the house is boring as what a usual old house is, she's constantly annoyed by a local "stalker" boy, and her neighbors seem to act a little odd for her liking. But Coraline finds some interesting things to talk about when she discovers a secret door, which leads her into an alternate reality of her life, with extremely loving parents, fun and games, and even things that are highly impossible in the real world, such as a talking cat, but the more time Coraline spends in her alternate world, she realizes that things aren't what they seem, especially when the Other Mother, who has buttons on her eyes, demands that buttons should be placed on Coraline's eyes.

As the film was progressing in my mind, I kept thinking that Tim Burton could have made this movie, as the dark, eerie visuals is something that Burton masters in. While Burton was not involved in making this film, clearly the film does have that cool Tim Burton vibe, and it works, brilliantly. What fascinates me most about the film is how the style of the visuals change on how tense the situations get, especially in the alternate reality moments, where the colors pop when everything's happy, and extremely spooky when it's just a terrifying nightmare. Claymation was perfect for Coraline, as I wouldn't have pictured a film this dark in anything CGI. 

The voice casting in Coraline in fantastic. We have Dakota Fanning who voices the title character, and she nails it. I loved that Fanning was able to convey an 11-year old girl with an adventure side, and when things are extremely nightmarish that would have creeped me out in a heartbeat, she knew how to overcome it without being scared. Simply put, Coraline Jones is an excellent role model for any child who is scared of anything related to anything dark and spooky, possibly one of the best female role models in a modern animated film, up there with Mulan, Rapunzel, and Anna from Frozen. The other fantastic, standout performance is Teri Hatcher as both mothers. And like Fanning, Hatcher voices her role fantastically, particularly the Other Mother. The obsessive behavior of this supposedly nice but terrifyingly freaky character is brilliantly portrayed, reminding me a little bit of Judith Anderson's creepy performance in Hitchcock's Rebecca. There's also John Hodgman as the father, who's role is delightfully fun, Dawn French and Jennifer Saunders as two retired British actresses, who also delight in oddness, and Ian McShane as the weird Mr. Bobinsky, and is also fun.

The film is scored by French composer Bruno Coulais, a composer that I had never heard of before watching Coraline, and like what Danny Elfman would do in a Tim Burton film, Coulais delights in sounds of brilliant creepiness and strong instrumentations. Would like to see him score more mainstream animation films, particularly those that are claymated, if more films are made of course. 

When I watch an animated film, I'd like for it to appeal to its target audience, mainly children, and while I was very impressed with Coraline, I don't think the film is that appropriate for the youngest of children. There are things in Coraline that very much pushes the limits of its PG rating, such as crude sexual jokes, obsessive behavior that would very much confuse children, the creepy visuals, and a very wrong Burlesque scene featuring the odd British actresses, one wearing an outfit that a stripper would wear, and one that's shown in front of kids. I know there's animators that like to sneak adult humor in so-called kids films, and most of the time, I'm OK with it, particularly in DreamWorks films, but it was a little over the top in Coraline. Plus the dark content would likely scar a two-year-old for life. This wouldn't be a film I would show to my children, if I ever have children of course, until teen years. I'm surprised that the film did not get a PG-13 rating for the Burlesque scene alone! Oh well, at least I had some enjoyment out of it and I would show this to older children over Mars Needs Moms, which in my book, will scar everyone for life.

The film isn't 100% family-friendly as what to expect in animation (or Claymation in that matter), but for those that can handle the dark, edgy content (like over the age of 16), Coraline is visually wonderful, dark, and filled with grand imagination. With this and The Nightmare Before Christmas, Henry Selick, along with Tim Burton, is a visual genius in stop motion and if both continue to make claymated films, along with the Laika studio, then maybe, just maybe, stop motion might get the attention that it truly deserves. As for now, I'm excited about seeing The Boxtrolls later in the year and have higher hopes on Laika's other feature that I have yet to see, ParaNorman.

From the mind of the acclaimed writer who brought to you Stardust and American Gods, and the director who brought to you Nightmare Before Christmas, comes a fantastical, odd and eerily dark tale of Coraline. 

The Joneses have just moved to a new house. Caroline Jones finds her life boring and thinks that her parents do not care for her one bit. She meets Wybie and rather sinister-looking black cat, and receives a rather strange doll which resembles her. Soon, she is led through a small doorway into another world, which is almost like her own home, but livelier. It is a place where her parents are fun - only with buttons as eyes - and she can do her favourite things all day until she goes to sleep. The next morning, she would wake up back in her real home again. Attracted by the place, she makes another trip back there, but soon discovers that things there are a little too good to be true. Only when it is too late does she realise her terrible mistake. 

This is the first animated feature I have watched in quite a while now and it is indeed refreshing, especially seeing as it incorporates fantasy, horror and Gothic elements - some of my favourite genres. Based on the Hugo-winning novella by author Neil Gaiman, this film adaptation went on to win several awards at the Annie Awards and was nominated at both the Oscars and Golden Globes for best animated feature. 

On the main aspects, the voice acting is pretty good. Dakota Fanning's voice is perfect for Coraline and Keith David (Crash, Requiem for a Dream) as the cat is bone-chilling. Apart from that, I was pleasantly surprised to hear British comedy legends, Dawn French and Jennifer Saunders voicing two former burlesque dancers leaving under Coraline's house. The screenplay is well-written and the overall pacing of the film is perfect. 

On the technical aspects, the production design is both gorgeous and harrowing at the same time. While the designs resemble those of Night Before Christmas and Corpse Bride, it contains some of its own elements. The stop-motion animation is also pretty good and it actually makes the villain all the more scary. The music by Bruno Coulais is haunting, bone-chilling and out of this world. Simply beautiful. 


Overall, this is a beautifully dark and haunting animated feature with an important message to children - be careful for what you wish for. The wish might just end up devouring you, instead.

I got to see Neil Gaiman at George Mason University last fall as he read excerpts from his stories and told the story of why Coraline became a kid's book (it's actually quite funny). Seeing this brilliant man's work on the big screen is a great thing to see as he's both imaginative and an entertaining story teller. Coraline follows the story of young Coraline Jones, who has just moved from Michigan to Pink Palace Apartments. As she grows bored by the minute, she discovers a mysterious door. When she first opens it, it's just a brick wall. But, at night, she discovers a whole new world where everything seems to fit to her wants and desires. The only real difference between this world and the real world is that everyone seems to have buttons for eyes. It seems like a dream come true for her because they're all listening to her and she's getting everything she wants. That is, until she discovers that this world is in a very dark place. What I loved the most about Coraline is that it does something that not many kids films do nowadays. It actually has a dark and eerie story to it. Everything goes great until one scene in particular when Coraline learns what she needs to do in order to stay, which changes the tone of the story. I enjoyed every minute of the tonal shift because it came off as extremely creepy while also trying not to terrify littler children (but this should still probably be seen by kids a little over 8). There's dark subject material that feels like a breath of fresh air from other generic family films. The visual effects in this film look dynamite for a stop motion film. The way the visuals appear greatly reflect the mood of the story, making sure not to be inconsistent. The acting, for the most part, was pretty good. None of the child voices had me cringing and the adult actors do their part pretty well too. The only major quarrels I have with this film are the fact that some of the body language used doesn't match what they're saying and some of the lines are extremely cheesy and not very pleasant to hear. Other than that, Coraline is a very well made animated film that does a good job of steering away from the other clichéd family films by adding some darkness to the tale. It's well worth the time to see it and, though you might not be scared, you might leave the theater just a bit creeped out.

I finally caught up with this. I'm surprised by how actually kind of scary this film is and not just as a kids' film. It's actually pretty creepy as a film period. Henry Selick blends both creepy and whimsical visuals very well (sometimes at the same time) and Dakota Fanning gives probably my favorite performance from her. It may not be as good as "Nightmare Before Christmas" but it's pretty darn close.
